text: People act like having a startup fail is the worst thing that can happen to you. And man, that's not even in the top 10. It's bad, I've done it, it's awful. It's really bad, but far worse is to be in a company that won't die, a zombie, undead company that you hate, but you can't leave. Oof, have I met people like that, and we're having a mental health crisis among founders that's not talked about enough.
speaker: Eric Ries
context: Lenny asks Eric about his career and current work. Eric reflects on the mental health challenges facing entrepreneurs and different types of business failures. He explains that while startup failure is painful, being trapped in a 'zombie' company that won't die but also won't succeed is far worse for founders' wellbeing. Eric emphasizes the often-overlooked psychological toll of building companies that become forces founders no longer believe in.
text_ko: 사람들이 마치 스타트업(startup)이 망하는 게 인생 최악인 것처럼 말해요. 근데 솔직히 그건 최악 10위권에도 안 들어요. 물론 나쁘죠 — 저도 겪어봤고 정말 끔찍했어요. 그런데 훨씬 더 심한 건 도무지 끝나지 않는 회사, 즉 좀비 회사(zombie company)에 갇혀 있는 거예요. 그 회사를 진짜 싫어하는데도 떠날 수가 없는 상황이요. 아, 그런 사람들 정말 많이 만났어요. 창업자들(founders) 사이에 정신 건강 위기(mental health crisis)가 오고 있는데 이 얘기는 충분히 안 되고 있어요.
text_zh: 大家总觉得创业失败是天塌下来的事儿，哥们儿，这连前十都排不上。确实很糟心，我经历过，真的很难受。但更要命的是待在一个死不了的公司里，就像僵尸企业一样，你恨死了但又走不了。天哪，我见过太多这样的人了，创始人的心理健康危机真的没有得到足够重视。
text_es: La gente actúa como si tener una startup que fracase fuera lo peor que te puede pasar. Y hermano, eso ni siquiera está en el top 10. Está cabrón, lo he vivido, es horrible. Está muy mal, pero mucho peor es estar en una empresa que no se muere, una empresa zombie, muerta en vida que odias, pero no puedes irte. Uff, he conocido gente así, y tenemos una crisis de salud mental entre fundadores de la que no se habla lo suficiente.

text: And I would go and have these meetings, and I'm not making this up, people would yell at me in the meeting. I would get yelled at. In fact, I would be asked not very kindly to leave, and I'd be like, "I don't understand. What are you yelling... Why are you mad at me? You asked me for this meeting." And they'd be like... I'm just telling you what I witnessed with my own eyes. We at IMVU, we shipped product 50 times a day on average at a time when people were lucky to be doing it monthly if they were really advanced.
speaker: Eric Ries
context: Lenny asks Eric about his early career and how he didn't expect to have such impact on startup culture. Eric describes the early days before Lean Startup became popular, when he would meet with VCs and startup teams to share his engineering methods. His practices of shipping code 50 times per day seemed impossible to most people at the time, leading to hostile reactions in meetings where people literally asked him to leave.
text_ko: 그리고 그런 회의에 제가 가면, 이건 제가 꾸며낸 얘기가 아니에요. 회의에서 사람들이 저한테 소리를 지르곤 했어요. 심지어 별로 친절하게 나가라고 하기도 했고요. 저는 "무슨 소리인지 모르겠어요. 왜 저한테 화를 내세요? 이 회의를 요청하신 분들이잖아요" 이렇게 말하곤 했어요. 사람들이 뭐라고 하냐면… 저는 그냥 제 눈으로 직접 본 걸 말하는 거예요. 저희 IMVU는 그때 평균 하루에 제품을 하루에 50번씩 배포(ship)했어요. 그때 다른 회사들은, 정말 앞선 곳조차 운이 좋아야 한 달에 한 번 정도 했던 시절이었죠.
text_zh: 我就去参加这些会议，我没瞎说啊，会上真有人冲我吼。就是有人对我大喊大叫。甚至还有人很不客气地让我滚蛋，我就懵了，"我搞不懂啊，你吼什么...你干嘛对我发火？明明是你要求开这个会的。" 然后他们就...我说的都是我亲眼看到的。我们IMVU那会儿，平均一天发布产品50次，要知道那个年代，别人能做到一个月发布一次就算很牛了。
text_es: Y yo iba a esas reuniones, y no me lo estoy inventando, la gente me gritaba en plena junta. Me gritaban de verdad. De hecho, me pedían no muy amablemente que me fuera, y yo me quedaba como "No entiendo. ¿Por qué me están gritando...? ¿Por qué están enojados conmigo? Ustedes me pidieron esta reunión." Y ellos como que... Solo les estoy contando lo que vi con mis propios ojos. Nosotros en IMVU, lanzábamos producto 50 veces al día en promedio, en una época donde la gente tenía suerte si lo hacía mensualmente, y eso si eran realmente avanzados.

text: We charge onto the field and no other army ever came to charge us back, just we won by default because the people who were doing it the old way didn't really like it or want... It was very few defenders of the old way. There were very few people who came out and said, "Actually, no, Stage-Gate is actually still the correct product idea. You've got it wrong." It never happened.
speaker: Eric Ries
context: Lenny asks about the current state of the Lean Startup movement. Eric explains how he expected the movement to face fierce opposition from traditional business methodologies, using a military metaphor to describe the anticipated 'battle of ideas.' However, he was surprised to discover there were very few people defending old product development approaches like Stage-Gate methodology - the victory came by default rather than through intellectual combat.
text_ko: 우리가 전장으로 뛰어들었는데 아무도 우리를 다시 공격하러 오지 않았어요. 그래서 그냥 자동으로 이긴 셈이었어요. 옛 방식으로 하던 사람들은 사실 그 방식을 별로 좋아하지도, 원하지도 않았거든요. 옛 방식을 지키려던 방어자는 거의 없었어요. "아니에요, 스테이지-게이트(Stage-Gate)가 여전히 옳은 제품 아이디어예요. 당신들이 틀렸어요."라고 선뜻 나선 사람은 정말 드물었고 그런 일은 일어나지 않았어요.
text_zh: 我们冲到战场上，结果根本没有其他队伍来跟我们对抗，就这样不战而胜了，因为那些还在用老方法的人其实心里也不太认同，也不想继续那样做...为旧方式辩护的人真的很少很少。基本上没什么人站出来说"不对，阶段门(Stage-Gate)流程才是正确的产品开发思路，你们搞错了。"这种情况压根就没发生过。
text_es: Nos lanzamos al campo de batalla y nunca apareció otro ejército que nos hiciera frente, simplemente ganamos por descarte porque la gente que hacía las cosas a la antigua no estaba realmente convencida o no quería... Había muy pocos defensores del método tradicional. Muy poca gente salió a decirnos "No, esperen, el modelo Stage-Gate sigue siendo la forma correcta de manejar las ideas de producto. Ustedes están equivocados." Eso nunca pasó.

text: I wrote an article, God, five or 10 years ago. God, I can't even remember how many years ago now. It was like Top Misconceptions About Lean Startup, and it was like, "Number one, lean means cheap, so if you're doing Lean Startup, it means you're not raising money." And it's like, "That's not true." And then kind of I remember what they are... And they're all still prevalent, nothing's changed. I could write that same article today.
speaker: Eric Ries
context: Lenny asks Eric about misconceptions regarding Lean Startup that frustrate him most. Eric recalls writing an article years ago addressing common misunderstandings about his methodology. The biggest misconception is that 'lean' means 'cheap' and that Lean Startup companies shouldn't raise venture capital. He expresses frustration that despite years of clarification, these same misconceptions persist unchanged in the startup community.
text_ko: 와, 한 5년 아니면 10년쯤 전에 글을 썼어요. 지금 몇 년 전인지도 기억이 안 나네요. '린 스타트업(Lean Startup)에 대한 가장 큰 오해들' 같은 글이었는데, 첫 번째가 '린(lean)은 저렴하다는 뜻이라 린 스타트업(Lean Startup)을 하면 투자를 안 받는다'는 거였어요. 근데 그건 사실이 아니에요. 다른 오해들도 뭐였는지 기억나고… 근데 그 모든 오해가 아직도 널리 퍼져 있고 달라진 게 하나도 없어요. 오늘도 똑같은 글을 쓸 수 있을 것 같아요.
text_zh: 我记得我写过一篇文章，天哪，大概是五年前还是十年前吧。天哪，我现在都记不清到底是多少年前了。那篇文章叫《关于精益创业(Lean Startup)的几大误区》之类的，第一条就是"精益就等于省钱，所以如果你在做精益创业(Lean Startup)，就意味着你不打算融资。"然后我就说，"这完全不对。"我大概还记得其他几条是什么...现在这些误区还是到处都是，一点都没变。我今天写同样的文章内容都不用改。
text_es: Escribí un artículo hace, Dios, cinco o diez años. Dios, ya ni me acuerdo de hace cuántos años. Era algo como "Los principales mitos sobre Lean Startup", y decía: "Número uno, lean significa barato, entonces si estás haciendo Lean Startup, significa que no estás levantando capital." Y yo decía: "Eso no es cierto." Y más o menos me acuerdo de cuáles eran... Y todos siguen ahí, no ha cambiado nada. Podría escribir ese mismo artículo hoy.

text: But the thing that gets missed from the story is that Facebook's already started at that point, it's already being successful, and they're on the break between semesters on the summer. And Dustin Moskovitz, and Mark Zuckerberg, and Adam D'Angelo, and I forget who else are living in this house together. Someone told me this story about what they were actually working on at that time. It wasn't Facebook.
speaker: Eric Ries
context: Lenny asks about pivoting and how common it is for startups to change direction completely. Eric shares a lesser-known Facebook story to illustrate how even successful founders can miss recognizing their breakthrough products. He describes how Mark Zuckerberg and his co-founders were living in Palo Alto during summer break, working on other projects instead of Facebook, even though Facebook was already showing success - demonstrating how difficult it can be to recognize when you've found product-market fit.
text_ko: 그 이야기에서 사람들이 잘 놓치는 건, 그때쯤엔 이미 페이스북이 시작돼서 성공하고 있던 시점이라는 거예요. 게다가 그들은 여름 방학 중이었고, 더스틴 모스코비츠, 마크 저커버그, 아담 디앤젤로, 그리고 누가 더 있었는지 잘 기억은 안 나지만 다 같이 한 집에서 살고 있었어요. 누군가가 그들이 실제로 그때 뭘 하고 있었는지에 대해 얘기해줬는데, 그건 페이스북이 아니었어요.
text_zh: 但是大家都忽略了一个关键点，就是那时候Facebook其实已经起步了，而且已经做得挺成功的，当时正好是暑假放假期间。然后Dustin Moskovitz、Mark Zuckerberg、Adam D'Angelo，还有其他几个人，我忘了是谁了，反正他们就住在一个房子里。有人跟我说了个故事，讲他们那时候真正在忙什么。结果不是Facebook。
text_es: Pero lo que se pierde en esa historia es que Facebook ya había empezado en ese momento, ya estaba funcionando bien, y estaban en las vacaciones de verano entre semestres. Y Dustin Moskovitz, Mark Zuckerberg, Adam D'Angelo, y no me acuerdo quién más estaban viviendo juntos en esa casa. Alguien me contó esta historia sobre en qué estaban trabajando realmente en ese momento. No era Facebook.

text: So first of all, if you're asking whether you should pivot or not you probably know the answer already. That's the first thing to just straight up say. People call me sometimes they're like "I want to know if I have product market fit." Well, the fact that you have time to call me and ask me this question already tells me the answer. If you have had product-market fit you would not have time for this.
speaker: Eric Ries
context: Lenny asks Eric for tactical advice on how founders should decide whether to pivot or stay the course, especially relevant for struggling startups. Eric provides a blunt reality check: if founders have time to contemplate whether they should pivot, they probably already know they need to. He explains that true product-market fit creates such overwhelming demand and urgency that founders don't have time for philosophical discussions - they're too busy handling growth.
text_ko: 먼저, 피벗(pivot)을 해야 할지 말아야 할지 묻고 계시다면 아마 스스로 이미 답을 알고 계실 거예요. 그걸 솔직히 말하는 게 먼저예요. 가끔 저한테 전화하시는 분들이 "제품-시장 적합성(product-market fit)이 있는지 알고 싶다"고 해요. 그런데 저에게 전화를 걸어 이런 질문을 할 시간 자체가 있다는 사실만으로도 답이 드러나요. 진짜로 제품-시장 적합성이 있었다면 이런 질문을 할 시간이 없었을 거예요.
text_zh: 首先啊，如果你在纠结要不要转型(pivot)，其实你心里已经有答案了。这话我得直说。有时候有人打电话给我说"我想知道我们是不是已经找到了产品市场契合度(product market fit)"。其实你有时间打电话问我这个问题，就已经说明答案了。如果你真的找到了产品市场契合度(product market fit)，你根本没时间打这个电话。
text_es: Primero que nada, si te estás preguntando si deberías hacer un pivot o no, probablemente ya sabes la respuesta. Eso es lo primero que hay que decir de frente. A veces me llama gente y me dice "quiero saber si tengo product-market fit". Bueno, el hecho de que tengas tiempo para llamarme y preguntarme esto ya me dice la respuesta. Si realmente tuvieras product-market fit, no tendrías tiempo ni para esto.

text: The aperture of possible futures that AI makes possible is so incredibly wide. And Predicting it requires a really deep understanding of a bunch of empirical questions, as far as I can tell, nobody knows the answers to right now. So given that it's not knowable what's going to happen... You're not an expert enough. As far as I can tell nobody knows. The people who are most expert are actively doing the research to try to find out the thing that will help us predict.
speaker: Eric Ries
context: Lenny asks about how AI is changing the lean startup approach and product development. Eric addresses the uncertainty many people feel about AI's impact on business and society. He explains his framework for taking ethical action despite not knowing what the future holds - the range of possible AI outcomes is so vast that even experts are still researching fundamental questions, so individuals shouldn't feel paralyzed by their lack of expertise.
text_ko: AI가 열어주는 가능한 미래의 폭(aperture)은 정말 어마어마하게 넓어요. 그걸 예측하려면 여러 경험적 질문들(empirical questions)에 대해 아주 깊이 이해해야 하고, 제 판단으로는 지금은 아무도 그 답을 모르는 것 같아요. 그래서 앞으로 무슨 일이 일어날지 알 수 없다면, 당신은 아직 충분한 전문가가 아니에요. 가장 전문적인 사람들은 바로 예측에 도움이 될 요소를 찾아내기 위해 활발히 연구하고 있어요.
text_zh: AI带来的未来可能性简直太广了，广得不可思议。要想预测这些，你得对一大堆实际问题有非常深入的理解，但据我所知，现在没人知道这些问题的答案。既然无法预知会发生什么...你还不够专业。据我了解，没人真正知道。那些最专业的人也在积极做研究，试图找到能帮我们做预测的东西。
text_es: La gama de futuros posibles que abre la IA es increíblemente amplia. Y predecir todo esto requiere un entendimiento muy profundo de un montón de cuestiones empíricas que, por lo que veo, nadie sabe responder ahora mismo. Entonces, dado que no se puede saber qué va a pasar... no eres lo suficientemente experto. Por lo que puedo ver, nadie lo sabe. Las personas que más saben del tema están justamente haciendo la investigación para tratar de encontrar lo que nos ayude a predecir.
